The file @docs/build_plans/2025-06-26_0000_add_downloading/plan.md contains a plan for how to implement the requirements for a goal. However, the plan has many milestones.

I want you to create a new Markdown file for each milestone. Name each file `milestone_XX.md` with `XX` being the milestone number. For example, the first file will be `milestone_01.md`. These files will be in the same directory as $ARGUMENTS

The "Executive Summary" section must be at the top of each milestone file.

**IMPORTANT:** DO NOT MODIFY ANY PART OF ANY MILESTONE OR STEP. EACH MILESTONE AND STEP MUST REMAIN EXACTLY AS IT IS DEFINED IN $ARGUMENTS

The milestone in each file must end with the following steps. Make sure to give these steps sequential numbers like the other steps in the milestone.

- Step: Linting and Type Checking
  - Run and fix all linting issues:
    - `npm run lint` passes without warnings
    - TypeScript compilation succeeds
    - No `any` types unless absolutely necessary
    - Consistent code formatting
- Step: User Code Review
  - Stop making changes to files
  - Ask the user to review the code
  - Proceed to the next step once the user has finished reviewing the code
- Step: Commit the Changes
  - Use the `git commit` command to commit the changes to the Git repository
  - Write a concise commit message that captures the name of the step and a summary of the changes

input.content:
# Implementation Plan: Chrome Extension Image Downloading

## Executive Summary

This plan implements image downloading functionality for a Chrome extension built with React/TypeScript. The system will detect supported pages, display a download button, queue images for downloading, and show download progress in a "Downloads" tab. The implementation follows a phased approach with comprehensive error handling and testing.

## Milestone 1.1: Core Infrastructure Setup

**Objective**: Establish foundation for download functionality

**Success Criteria**:

- Manifest updated with correct permissions
- Core types defined and exported
- Debug logging configured

### Step 1.1.1: Update Chrome Extension Manifest

- Add required permissions to `manifest.json`:
  - `"activeTab"` for content script injection
  - `"scripting"` for Manifest V3 content script injection
  - `"downloads"` for Chrome Downloads API
  - `"storage"` for accessing download directory settings
- Add host permissions for supported domains:
  - `"*://127.0.0.1:4000/*"` for localhost testing
  - `"*://pictoa.com/*"` for Pictoa image albums
- Verify existing permissions are compatible

### Step 1.1.2: Create Core TypeScript Types

- Create `src/types/downloads.ts` with:
  - `DownloadItem` interface (id, filename, url, status, progress)
  - `DownloadGroup` interface (id, title, url, status, items)
  - `DownloadState` interface (groups)
  - `DownloadStatus` enum (queued, downloading, downloaded, failed, cancelled)
  - `GroupStatus` enum (downloading, failed, cancelled, queued, downloaded)
  - Message types for Chrome runtime communication

### Step 1.1.3: Create Page Detection Types

- Create `src/types/pages.ts` with:
  - `SupportedPage` interface (domain, path pattern, title extractor, image URL extractor)
  - `PageExtractor` interface for title and image URL extraction functions
  - Configuration for localhost and Pictoa pages

### Step 1.1.4: Set Up Debug Logging

- Create download-specific debug namespaces using existing debug package:
  - `download:content` for content script logging
  - `download:background` for background script logging
  - `download:react` for React app logging
- Follow existing project patterns for debug logging

### Step 1.1.5: Linting and Type Checking

- Run and fix all linting issues:
  - `npm run lint` passes without warnings
  - TypeScript compilation succeeds
  - No `any` types unless absolutely necessary
  - Consistent code formatting

### Step 1.1.6: User Code Review

- Stop making changes to files
- Ask the user to review the code
- Proceed to the next step once the user has finished reviewing the code

### Step 1.1.7: Commit the Changes

- Use the `git commit` command to commit the changes to the Git repository
- Write a concise commit message that captures the name of the step and a summary of the changes

file.content:
# Milestone 1: Foundation & Setup

## Executive Summary

This milestone establishes the foundation for download functionality by updating the Chrome extension manifest with required permissions, creating core TypeScript types for download management, and setting up debug logging infrastructure.

## Objective

Establish foundation for download functionality

## Step 1.1.1: Update Chrome Extension Manifest

- Add required permissions to `manifest.json`:
  - `"activeTab"` for content script injection
  - `"scripting"` for Manifest V3 content script injection
  - `"downloads"` for Chrome Downloads API
  - `"storage"` for accessing download directory settings
- Add host permissions for supported domains:
  - `"*://127.0.0.1:4000/*"` for localhost testing
  - `"*://pictoa.com/*"` for Pictoa image albums
- Verify existing permissions are compatible

## Step 1.1.2: Create Core TypeScript Types

- Create `src/types/downloads.ts` with:
  - `DownloadItem` interface (id, filename, url, status, progress)
  - `DownloadGroup` interface (id, title, url, status, items)
  - `DownloadState` interface (groups)
  - `DownloadStatus` enum (queued, downloading, downloaded, failed, cancelled)
  - `GroupStatus` enum (downloading, failed, cancelled, queued, downloaded)
  - Message types for Chrome runtime communication

## Step 1.1.3: Create Page Detection Types

- Create `src/types/pages.ts` with:
  - `SupportedPage` interface (domain, path pattern, title extractor, image URL extractor)
  - `PageExtractor` interface for title and image URL extraction functions
  - Configuration for localhost and Pictoa pages

## Step 1.1.4: Set Up Debug Logging

- Create download-specific debug namespaces using existing debug package:
  - `download:content` for content script logging
  - `download:background` for background script logging
  - `download:react` for React app logging
- Follow existing project patterns for debug logging

## Success Criteria

- Manifest updated with correct permissions
- Core types defined and exported
- Debug logging configured

## Step 1.1.5: Linting and Type Checking

- Run and fix all linting issues:
  - `npm run lint` passes without warnings
  - TypeScript compilation succeeds
  - No `any` types unless absolutely necessary
  - Consistent code formatting

## Step 1.1.6: User Code Review

- Stop making changes to files
- Ask the user to review the code
- Proceed to the next step once the user has finished reviewing the code

## Step 1.1.7: Commit the changes

- Use the `git commit` command to commit the changes to the Git repository
- Write a concise commit message that captures the name of the step and a summary of the changes
